questions.question: ……………………………. missing the train, I reached on time.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition. We use it before an ing form which acts as its object.

questions.question: …………………………… I missed the train, I reached on time.
questions.description: Though is a conjunction. It is used to introduce a clause.

questions.question: I worked hard ………………………., I failed the test.
questions.description: However is used to introduce an idea that contrasts with the previous idea.

questions.question: ………………………….. she is an atheist, she is a kind hearted woman.
questions.description: Though and although mean the same.

questions.question: ……………………………… working two jobs she does not earn enough.
questions.description: Despite and in spite of are interchangeable.

questions.question: I didn’t know anyone at the party ……………………………, that didn’t stop me from having a nice time.
questions.description: However is used to introduce an idea that contrasts with the previous idea.

questions.question: Tired …………………………. I was, I went swimming.
questions.description: As and though can be used in a special structure after an adjective or adverb. In this case, they both mean although.

questions.question: His dad was angry, ……………………………. he had failed his exam.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction because of is a preposition.

questions.question: I missed the last bus, ………………………… I had to walk home.
questions.description: So indicates the result or effect.

questions.question: …………………………. he hadn’t applied on time, he could not get the job.
questions.description: Since is used to introduce the reason.

questions.question: …………………………… she is ill, she cannot go to work.
questions.description: Because indicates the reason.

questions.question: …………………………… he could not offer any satisfactory explanation he lost his job.
questions.description: As indicates the reason.

questions.question: I shall not go ……………….. they invite me.
questions.description: Except is not equivalent to unless.

questions.question: I shall not go ……………………. you do.
questions.description: Without does not mean unless.

questions.question: I went ………………….. him.
questions.description: Without is a preposition and it is followed by a noun or noun phrase.

questions.question: He speaks ……………………. his father.
questions.description: Like is a preposition. It is followed by a noun or pronoun.

questions.question: He walks …………………….. his father does,
questions.description: As is a conjunction. It is followed by a clause.

questions.question: Scarcely had he gone, ………………….. someone knocked at the door.
questions.description: Scarcely should be followed by when or before, and not by than.

questions.question: No sooner had he returned ………………….. he was off again.
questions.description: No sooner is followed by than.

questions.question: This is as good as that, …………….. not better.
If I do not speak of her it is ………………… I have nothing to do with her.
He washed neither his hands ………………… his face.
He lost not only his ticket …………….. his luggage.
questions.description: The correct pattern is not only / but also.

questions.question: …………………… they tried hard, they could not succeed.
questions.description: Although is a conjunction. We use it to connect two clauses.
